body: Made a simple test for you, if you want it: http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/c98a25025121b9315a66

issue.title: Preserve polygon exterior/interior ring ordering.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
According to GeoJSON, the first ring in a polygon should be the exterior, and subsequent rings should be holes that are inside the exterior ring.  This fix ensures that the rejoining of clipped segments preserves these semantics, by generating multiple polygons if necessary rather than generating all rings within a single polygon as it did previously.

Fixes #1558.

body: Reopened, since the previous fix caused a performance regression (#1577).

issue.title: Performance regression in clipping.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Unfortunately, it looks like b0659e0ce28d08faf88cd9c4086bf9d2022ac85d is a major performance regression in the [rotating Ocean example](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/6713736). In 3.3.6 I get a reliable 60 FPS, but in 3.3.7 I get about 20 FPS.

I created a [revert-clip-extent branch](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/tree/revert-clip-extent) to test. Here‚Äôs the difference I see in the CPU profiler.

Before:
![screen shot 2013-10-10 at 5 23 22 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/1311452/7bcb5bae-320b-11e3-820c-f4de3fcd763a.png)

After:

![screen shot 2013-10-10 at 5 23 32 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/1311453/81de131a-320b-11e3-99ef-c9035d1eddc7.png)

So, a lot of time in d3_geo_pointInPolygon and d3_geo_clipPolygon, naturally.

issue.title: topojson --projection doesn‚Äôt preserve polygon semantics

repository.name: topojson
repository.description: An extension of GeoJSON that encodes topology! üåê

issue.body:
This is a reflection of mbostock/d3#1558. A simple test case:

``` bash
topojson \
  -o world.json \
  --projection 'd3.geo.mercator().translate([480,480])' \
  -- countries=ne_50m_admin_0_countries.shp
```

And rendered like so in the browser:

``` html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<meta charset="utf-8">
<body>
<script src="http://d3js.org/d3.v3.min.js"></script>
<script src="http://d3js.org/topojson.v1.min.js"></script>
<script>

var svg = d3.select("body").append("svg")
    .attr("width", 960)
    .attr("height", 960);

d3.json("world.json", function(error, world) {
  if (error) return console.error(error);

  svg.append("path")
      .datum(topojson.feature(world, world.objects.countries))
      .attr("d", d3.geo.path().projection(null));
});

</script>
```

When using the latest release of D3 (3.4.3), this produces the following output:

[![screen shot 2014-03-22 at 9 40 53 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/2491237/c56e6864-b1e0-11e3-8e8a-e95596b58ffe.png)](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/ae0ae4bd938e43d5eb3b)

When using mbostock/d3@b0659e0ce28d08faf88cd9c4086bf9d2022ac85d, we get the desired result:

[![screen shot 2014-03-22 at 9 44 46 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/2491241/500b816e-b1e1-11e3-97ba-bd8dbae127fc.png)](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/c485b2333da74992a3ad/a14cde12282234f5c655d7c00da53ae0e22eee40)

Now, unfortunately the fix to d3_geo_clipPolygon was a major [performance regression](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/issues/1577), and we only need to preserve the polygon semantics when we are reconstructing polygons, as is the case in d3.geo.project but not in the far more common case of rendering directly to SVG or Canvas. So, I‚Äôm wondering if there‚Äôs a way that we could selectively enable the slower-but-correct behavior for d3.geo.project, while preserving the faster-but-incorrect behavior for d3.geo.path. I expect it would be a pain to have two wildly divergent branches in d3.js, but maybe d3.geo.project or TopoJSON could patch in the other implementation? Just an idea.

body:
Given that we have a simple way to reconstruct polygon systems in d3.geo.project ( d3/d3-geo-projection@84fd562a057cc0db8c20871061559ddca61247d5), I don‚Äôt feel a strong need to require that d3.geo.stream implementations maintain polygon semantics. It feels simpler to relax this requirement and have clients that care about the semantics do this work themselves. Basically, we‚Äôd need to delete this line in the docs:

> The first ring of a polygon is the exterior ring, and is typically clockwise. Any subsequent rings indicate holes in the polygon, and are typically counterclockwise.

And change it to say the order of rings is undefined.

Bumping an old thread here. Many thanks for a great library.

If I understand things correctly, there is still a mismatch between the implementation and the docs on this point.

As of v1.2.3, the [docs](https://github.com/d3/d3-geo/blob/v1.2.3/README.md#stream_lineStart) say that _"[t]he first ring of a polygon is the exterior ring, and is typically clockwise"_ etc. However, the [implementation](https://github.com/d3/d3-geo/blob/v1.2.3/src/stream.js) does not seem to do so. I guess @mbostock's proposed solution (updating the docs to say that order is undefined) still works.

Or has this issue been fixed in some other way in d3 v4?

@rasmuse The docs you linked describe the _stream_ interface and are correct. d3.geoStream does not implement the stream interface: it streams a geometry object to something that implements the _stream_ interface, such as a projection. (See the [implementation of d3.geoPath](https://github.com/d3/d3-geo/blob/master/src/path/index.js#L19) for example usage of d3.geoStream.) This issue describes a bug specifically in d3.geoClipExtent, which does not preserve the polygon semantics of the stream as described in the top post. This is neither a bug in the documentation of the stream interface nor in d3.geoStream but in d3.geoClipExtent.
Thanks for the clarification. That makes perfect sense.

issue.title: d3.geoProject
issue.body: This was somewhat inadvertently removed in the 1.0 release. The implementation is arguably buggy in that it doesn‚Äôt preserve polygon semantics, but I will need this method to upgrade topojson to D3 4.1. Possibly it could be in a separate repository.

issue.title: projection stream's antimeridian cutting breaks polygons with holes

repository.name: d3-geo
repository.description: Geographic projections, spherical shapes and spherical trigonometry.

issue.body:
Not sure if bug, but it definitely bugs me a lot üòâ 

I described the problem I am experiencing in more detail at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/d3-js/1E1_EHPDeKU. It all boils down to the `geoStream -> projectionStream -> [my own consumer]` pipeline, where the "exterior first, interiors second" paradigm for polygons gets broken by antimeridian cutting.

This problem does not manifest when using the default geoPath for svg/canvas.
